questions.question: A 29-year-old African American man receives primaquine chemoprophylaxis before travelingfor a business trip. Four days later, he presents with jaundice and dark urine. Laboratoryinvestigations show anemia, reticulocytosis, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Theperipheral blood smear shows the presence of Heinz bodies. What is the most likely mode ofinheritance of the given clinical condition?
Which of the following is the most common trigger for hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency?
questions.explanation: The most common trigger for hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is infection. Viral hepatitis, pneumonia, and typhoid are the common infections that trigger hemolysis. Episodic hemolysis (both intravascular and extravascular) is seen in G6PD deficiency. It is due to exposures that cause oxidative stress. The triggers include: Infections - oxygen-derived free radicals produced by activated leukocytes, Drugs - Antimalarials (primaquine and chloroquine), Sulfonamides, Nitrofurantoin, and Diet - fava beans.

questions.question: Peripheral smear of a patient with viral hepatitis is given below. Which of the followingstatements is false about this finding?398

options.A: These are seen in G6PD deficiency
options.B: They are due to denaturation of globin chains
options.C: They are plucked out by macrophages in the spleen
options.D: They do not cause intravascular hemolysis

questions.explanation: The given peripheral smear shows Heinz bodies which are dark stained inclusion bodies in redcells. They can cause intravascular as well as extravascular hemolysis.In G6PD-deficiency, the RBCs are exposed to high levels of oxidants. This causes cross-linking ofreactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. The globin chains become denatured and formmembrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These can be detected by supravitalstaining.Heinz bodies can damage the membrane sufficiently to cause intravascular hemolysis.403As RBCs with Heinz bodies pass through the spleen, the macrophages pluck out the Heinz bodies.As a result, some of these partially devoured cells retain an abnormal shape i.e. as if a bite wastaken out of them. Such cells are called bite cells. Bite cells are trapped in splenic cords andremoved by phagocytes leading to extravascular hemolysis.The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.OMARROWHeinz bodies-Heinz body404OMARROWBite cellsMBite cell

questions.question: A patient with G6PD deficiency was suspected to have acute hemolytic episode. Which of thefollowing features would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.explanation: Acute hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is intravascular. This is marked by anaemia,hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria.These episodes are self-limited and intermittent. Reticulocytosis occurs during the recovery phase.Hence, features related to chronic hemolysis (e.g., splenomegaly, cholelithiasis) are absent.

questions.question: A 23-year-old food blogger presents with complaints of icterus and abdominal fullness. Shereturned yesterday from a vacation in Egypt where she tried fava beans. Her peripheral smearis given below. This condition is protective against which of the following malarial parasites?399
questions.explanation: The peripheral smear shows RBCs with anisopoikilocytosis with polychromasia and many bitecells (arrows) suggestive of G6PD deficiency. This condition is protective against Plasmodium405falciparum malaria.Malarial parasites preferentially invade RBCs which are rich in G6PD. G6PD deficiency causesoxidative stress and hemolysis, preferably in the older RBCs. Reticulocytes and youngerythrocytes have much higher G6PD activities and are less susceptible to oxidant damage.P. falciparum can invade erythrocytes of all ages. P. vivax, and P. ovale invade reticulocytes(immature erythrocytes) preferentially. Hence, a low G6PD level in older RBC is protective againstP. falciparum malaria.Episodic hemolysis in this condition can be triggered by fava beans which is a staple in Egyptiancuisine.The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true about G6PD-deficiency anemia?

options.A: Hemolytic episodes occur both intravascularly and extravascularly
options.B: G6PD Mediterranean deficiency is the most severe form.
options.C: Older RBCs are more prone to hemolysis than younger ones
options.D: Hemolysis continues as long as there is exposure to oxidant drugs

questions.explanation: OMARROWOMARROW-Heinz bodyM-Bite cell406Hemolysis in G6PD-deficiency anemia does not continue for the entire period that the patienttakes the offending drug. It stops after a few days.Two variants of G6PD, designated as G6PD- and G6PD Mediterranean, cause most of theclinically significant hemolytic anemias. The half-life of G6PD- is moderately reduced, whereasthat of G6PD Mediterranean is markedly reduced; hence, the severity of deficiency is greater withthe Mediterranean variant. The most common normal variant is G6PD B.The hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis. Thedamaged red cells are sequestered in the spleen and killedby macrophages, causing extravascular hemolysis. The oxidative stresses can denaturehemoglobin, resulting in intravascular hemolysis.In individuals with G6PD deficiency, acute intravascular hemolysis begins 2 to 3 days afterexposure to oxidants. Only older RBCs are at risk for lysis. The hemolytic episode isself-limited because hemolysis stops when only younger G6PD-replete red cells remain, even if thepatient continues to take the offending drug.

questions.question: What class of antibodies are involved in the most common form of immunohemolyticanaemia?
questions.explanation: Warm antibody type is the most common form of immunohemolytic anaemia. Most of thecausative antibodies in this condition belong to the IgG class.Immunohemolytic anaemia is caused by antibodies that cause premature destruction of the redcells. Based on the temperature at which the different types of antibodies bind to the RBCs stably,they are classified as:•Warm antibody type - most common• Cold agglutinin type• Cold hemolysin type

questions.question: Match the immunohemolytic anaemia with the type of hemolysis.
questions.explanation: The type of hemolysis seen in the different immunohemolytic anemia are:Autoimmune hemolytic anemias (AIHA) cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis.In warm antibody type, hemolysis is extravascular. IgG-coated red cells are phagocytosed anddestroyed in the spleen.In cold agglutinin type, hemolysis is extravascular and intravascular. In the peripheral vascularbed (low temperature), IgM binds to the red cells. This causes agglutination andcomplement-fixing. They are unbound when they reach the general circulation. However, the IgMinteraction causes deposition of sublytic quantities of C3b. It is an excellent opsonin, which leadsto the removal of RBCs by phagocytes in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow.Cold hemolysin type is a rare subtype of AIHA. Hemolysis is intravascular. IgG binds to the Pblood group antigen on the red cells, which leads to complement-mediated lysis.407TypeWarm antibodyHemolysisExtravascularCold agglutini Extravascular and intravasculnCold hemolysarIntravascularin

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with loss of consciousness. Onexamination, pallor, icterus and splenomegaly were noted. Her past history was significantfor meningitis 2 weeks ago which was treated with iv antibiotics. Lab investigations showedanemia and increased osmotic fragility. Which of the following statements is false regardingthe probable diagnosis?

options.A: Rh blood group complex are involved in the pathogenesis
options.C: Direct Coombs agglutination test is diagnostic

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced warm antibody type of immunohemolyticanemia. In this condition, primarily extravascular hemolysis is present. LDH may be increasedwhen there is hemolysis.Two different mechanisms for drug-induced immune hemolytic anemias are:Antigenic drugs:• Anemia occurs 1-2 weeks after initiation of large IV dose of the offending drug•••These drugs bind to red cell membrane and are recognised by anti-drug antibodiesThey can cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis⚫ E.g. penicillin, cephalosporins, quinidineTolerance-breaking drugs:• Antibodies are produced against red cell antigens, particularly Rh antigens• E.g. alpha-methyl dopa

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria?

options.A: IgG class of antibodies are involved
options.B: Antibodies are directed against Rh antigen
options.D: It mostly occurs in children following a viral infection

questions.explanation: In paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH), antibodies are directed against the P blood groupantigen.PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies classically. They are alsocalled Donath Landsteiner antibodies and are produced often in response to a viral infection. Thisantibody is a biphasic hemolysin. i.e., the antibody binds to RBC at colder temperature buthemolysis occurs at core temperature 37°C.This can cause substantial, sometimes fatal, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria. Mostcases are seen in children following viral infections and usually recover within 1 month.Immuno-hemolytic anaemias are of 3 types:408Antibody ty Antigen on the RBC surfacepeWarm aggluti IgGninTemperature for hemolysisRh antigen37°C or higherI antigen (adults)i antigen (in 30°C, usually 0-10°Cfants)Cold agglutini IgMnCold hemolys IgGinP antigenBiphasic hemolysis (37°C)

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia most commonlyseen?
questions.explanation: Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia is most commonly seen with disseminated intravascularcoagulation.It occurs in the following conditions:• Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)• Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)• Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS)• Malignant hypertension•Systemic lupus erythematosus•• Disseminated cancerA common pathogenic feature in these disorders is a microvascular lesion. Deposition of fibrinand platelets result in luminal narrowing. These vascular changes produce shear stresses. Thesechanges mechanically injure the passing red cells producing schistocytes or helmet cells on theperipheral smear.The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells.4091000 μm410
